text:
<@UN3EHV8RK> shared this in the tools channel a while back, but you might find it useful - this is a manual reporting template I set-up and use for a good few customers:

<https://content-career-growth.slack.com/archives/CN9UCQ92A/p1578667690001500>

attachments.fallback:
[January 10th, 2020 6:48 AM] ryan096: a little while back I was chatting to <@UJ99RGF7T> about getting useful performance insights from blogs with a tonnnnn of articles - basically how to overcome spreadsheet blindness and quickly identify meaningful trends and outliers

I shared a little spreadsheet hack I use all the time - using conditional formatting on month-on-month growth rates. Green represents positive improvements and gray negative changes. The stronger the color, the bigger the change.

nothing crazy, but I find this SO useful for being to scan performance data for 100/200/300+ articles and quickly see what's taking off and what's dying. it's great for getting to the "insight" part of performance reporting a little quicker

I threw together an example spreadsheet if anyone wants to see the formulae and formatting rules: <https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1_UVZrhNoKnfXnyRCW8BocCyHZrkCola0KfTjq_yhRZg/edit?usp=sharing>

does anyone else have any reporting or spreadsheet tips they fancy sharing? :nerd_face:
attachments.text:

nothing crazy, but I find this SO useful for being to scan performance data for 100/200/300+ articles and quickly see what's taking off and what's dying. it's great for getting to the "insight" part of performance reporting a little quicker

I threw together an example spreadsheet if anyone wants to see the formulae and formatting rules: <https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1_UVZrhNoKnfXnyRCW8BocCyHZrkCola0KfTjq_yhRZg/edit?usp=sharing>

text: Hey folks! Have you seen a good example of a fun way to announce a job opening? My agency is going to announce a pretty big opening for a content strategist next week, and I'd like to create something interesting that attracts a lot of organic attention

elements.text: Hey folks! Have you seen a good example of a fun way to announce a job opening? My agency is going to announce a pretty big opening for a content strategist next week, and I'd like to create something interesting that attracts a lot of organic attention

text: Like, part of me wants to create a fun Proust Questionnaire instead of asking for resumes

elements.text: Like, part of me wants to create a fun Proust Questionnaire instead of asking for resumes

text: <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Proust_Questionnaire>

attachments.title: Proust Questionnaire
attachments.text:
The Proust Questionnaire is a set of questions answered by the French writer Marcel Proust, and often used by modern interviewers.Proust answered the questionnaire in a confession album--a form of parlor game popular among Victorians. The album belonged to his friend Antoinette, daughter of future French President Félix Faure, titled "An Album to Record Thoughts, Feelings, etc."
The album was found in 1924 by Faure's son, and published in the French literary journal Les Cahiers du Mois. It was auctioned on May 27, 2003 for the sum of €102,000 ($113,609.46USD).Other historical figures who have answered confession albums are Oscar Wilde, Karl Marx, Arthur Conan Doyle, Stéphane Mallarmé, and Paul Cézanne.The French talk show host Bernard Pivot, used a similar questionnaire at the end of every episode of his show Apostrophes. Inspired by Bernard Pivot, James Lipton,  the host of the TV program Inside the Actors Studio, uses a similar questionnaire.  Lipton has often incorrectly characterized the questionnaire itself as an invention of Pivot.
A similar questionnaire is regularly seen on the back page of Vanity Fair magazine, answered by various celebrities. In October 2009, Vanity Fair launched an interactive version of the questionnaire, that compares individual answers to those of various luminaries.Another version of the questionnaire, as answered by various Canadian authors, is a regular feature on the radio program The Next Chapter.
